media.caption: His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche

text.headline: The Life of H.E Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche: A Timeline
text.text:
This interactive and evolving timeline offers a carefully curated introduction to the landmark journey of His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche — a revered master and one of the most influential figures in the Yungdrung Bön tradition. Tracing the arc of his spiritual path illuminates the key milestones of a life dedicated to wisdom, service, and the preservation of one of the world’s oldest spiritual lineages. It highlights his unwavering devotion, visionary leadership, and enduring contributions to the global transmission of Bön philosophy and practice.

While accounts of Yongdzin Rinpoche’s life exist in multiple languages — from blog entries to comprehensive biographies — this project marks the first digitally curated timeline of his life and legacy. Created for an increasingly digital world, it is both a tribute and a tool: a place for reflection, learning, and connection with a profound spiritual heritage.

This timeline is part of a broader, ongoing initiative conceived and built by Shima Beigi, under the guidance of Khenchen Tenpa Yungdrung Rinpoche, the abbot of Triten Norbutse Monastery. The information it contains has been meticulously compiled and reviewed by Khenchen Rinpoche to ensure its authenticity and integrity.

Far from attempting to provide a complete historical record, this living digital document serves as an accessible introduction to the extraordinary legacy of Yongdzin Rinpoche. It is intended to raise awareness of his life’s work and spiritual vision, and to support the wider effort of making his teachings available in digital formats that meet the needs of contemporary and future generations. This timeline, and the digital tools that will follow, are offered as part of that wider aspiration — to help seekers step into the current of his precious life, to encounter the quiet radiance of a master whose presence itself was a profound teaching, and to discover guideposts for embodying the timeless principles of Yungdrung Bön, as personified through the life of Yongdzin Rinpoche.

text.headline: Birth of Yongdzin Rinpoche
text.text: Yongdzin Rinpoche was born in 1926, the Year of the Fire Tiger, in Khamnyin, Khyungpo Karu, near Tengchen in eastern Tibet. His birth name was Chime Yungdrung, and his arrival was marked by auspicious signs, including a dream of his mother, Dongza Gachung, in which a white-clad yogi handed her a scripture, saying, This is your Bön destiny. His birthplace, Khyungpo, is tied to the Yungdrung Bön tradition and the ancient Khyung clan. His father, Drewo Pagsam, was from the humble Drewo clan, and his mother hailed from a respected lineage of thangka painters. Rinpoche's childhood was challenging. After his father's illness forced his mother to return home, he was raised by his uncle and aunt. Despite these difficulties, he demonstrated remarkable qualities, including kindness and compassion. Reflecting on his early years, Rinpoche said: There isn't really the time to talk about everything that has happened. Not all of it has been good, and my life has sometimes been quite hard. It was difficult from the very beginning. As a child, I nearly died.

text.headline: Moves to Tengchen Monastery
text.text: His Eminence Yongdzin Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche was raised in a family steeped in Bönpo heritage—his paternal uncle, the respected umzé (chant leader) Drewo Umzé, taught him to read, write, and chant sacred liturgies, while his maternal grandfather introduced him to the sacred art of thangka painting. Immersed in this rich cultural and spiritual environment, the young Tenzin Namdak developed a profound affinity for Yungdrung Bön, Tibet’s indigenous spiritual tradition. At the age of seven, he entered Tengchen Monastery, where his uncle served as chant master. There, he became deeply engaged in the rhythm of monastic life, learning basic liturgy and rituals and observing firsthand the disciplined, contemplative existence of the monks.

text.headline: Thangka Painting Apprentice and Mural Work in Tengchen
text.text: At the age of 10, Yongdzin Rinpoche began his formal apprenticeship in Thangka painting under the guidance of his uncle and maternal grandfather. Immersed in the sacred discipline of Tibetan iconography, he developed extraordinary artistic and meditative skills. Through painting, he entered the presence of great Bön masters, including Zöpa Rinpoche, who performed water blessings on Rinpoche as the youngest apprentice and had him paint a series of portraits of the principal Bön deities. His mastery opened many doors: Thangka painting became not only a devotional practice but also a means of livelihood and spiritual connection. Thanks to his talent, Rinpoche travelled to central Tibet at a time when such movement was rare, joining a team of Thangka painters.

text.headline: Mural Painting at Yungdrung Ling Monastery
text.text: At around the age of fourteen, Yongdzin Rinpoche travelled with his maternal uncle to Yungdrung Ling Monastery, one of the major monastic centres of the Bön tradition in central Tibet. Initially joining as an assistant mural painter, he participated in a large-scale sacred art project, contributing his skills in preparing pigments, sketching outlines, and refining details under the direction of senior artists. This experience not only deepened his technical mastery of Tibetan sacred art but also marked a pivotal moment in his spiritual journey. Immersed in the vibrant religious life of Yungdrung Ling, Rinpoche came under the guidance of senior Bön lamas, marking the integration of his artistic training into intellectual life.

text.headline: Became an ordained monk (Tenzin Namdak)
text.text: As a youth with a clear calling, Rinpoche sought the finest teachers and training within the Bön tradition. In 1942, at the age of 17, Chime Yungdrung undertook a trek trip to Menri Monastery in Tsang, central Tibet – the premier monastery of the Bön tradition to formally become a monk. There, he received monastic vows from two senior monks of Menri, Gyaltsab Tsakpé Gelong and Gegen Sonam Rinchen, taking the ordination name Tenzin Namdak, meaning “Pure Holder of the Buddha's Teachings.

text.headline: Moves to Tengchen Monastery and Pilgrimage to Sacred Sites
text.text: In 1942, shortly after his ordination, Yongdzin Rinpoche embarked on a life-changing pilgrimage with his two companions, crossing treacherous Himalayan passes to reach Muktinath (Chumig Gyatsa), where they witnessed the famed miraculous flames of earth, stone, and water—emanations of the Rigsum Gönpo, the Protectors of the Three Buddha Families. They then journeyed through Mustang via Tshokar and followed the Yeru Tsangpo River, approaching the sacred Mount Kailash, known in ancient Tibetan as Tisé, the soul-mountain of the ancient Zhangzhung kings and the site of Tönpa Shenrab Miwo's descent into Tibet. At Dzutrul Cave, Rinpoche and his companions began their circumambulation of Kailash. Amid snowstorms and extreme conditions, Rinpoche suffered frostbite in his right foot, limiting him to six circuits around the mountain. His companions faced their own hardships, with Sherab Tshultrim battling snow-blindness and completing three circuits, while Sherab Sengge managed seven or eight. They visited Jiu Monastery, Lho Trügo, Sera Lung, and Tazam, eventually arriving at Jadur Monastery, the seat of Jadur Nyima Özer, an eminent holder of the Dzogchen lineage. There, they performed the Matri ritual. Rinpoche's companions then returned to their homelands, but he continued alone to Yungdrung Ling Monastery, arriving in the fourth month of the Tibetan calendar. This pilgrimage not only deepened his spiritual resolve but also marked a decisive turning point in his commitment to the path of Yungdrung Bön, laying the foundation for the profound realisation and leadership that would define his life.

text.headline: Returns from Pilgrimage and Enters Yungdrung Ling Monastery
text.text: After completing a profound pilgrimage to Muktinath and the sacred Mount Kailash—encountering divine phenomena and enduring extreme physical hardship—Yongdzin Rinpoche returned to Yungdrung Ling Monastery in central Tibet. His two companions, exhausted by the journey, returned to their villages, but Rinpoche continued alone, arriving at Yungdrung Ling in the fourth month of the Tibetan calendar. This return marked a turning point in his spiritual life. Immersed in the deeply spiritual environment of one of the principal Bön monasteries, he began formal training under accomplished masters. The journey, which began as an act of devotion and artistic exploration, had now evolved into full dedication to the Bön monastic path—a moment that would define the trajectory of his entire life.

text.headline: Living and studying in the cave with yongdzin tshultrim Gyaltshen
text.text: Between 1944 and 1948, Rinpoche studied and practiced under his root teacher, Gangru Tsültrim Gyaltsen Rinpoche, a retired Lopön of Yungdrung Ling who was living in a remote cave by Juru Tso Lake in northern Tibet. There Yongdzin Rinpoche received intensive training in grammar, poetry, cosmology, and the entire framework of Sutra, Tantra, and Dzogchen. During his retreat with Gangru Tsültrim Gyaltsen, Yongdzin Rinpoche was invited to help create a Dutrisu mandala for a nearby monastery, despite restrictions against Khampas. He successfully completed the mandala and supported himself through painting and occasional offerings. Although living in hardship, he remained committed to studying and practising, reflecting that this was just one life's work. That winter, he journeyed to Lhasa, visited sacred sites, received advanced teachings on monastic discipline, cosmology, and Tantra, and practised Thögal in retreat. These experiences deepened his knowledge and led to his rare intellectual and spiritual maturity. In 1948, at the age of 23, he received major initiations, including Namdag, Künrig Drönma, Maseng, Khyungmar, and Tshedrub, and made handwritten copies of precious scriptures..

text.headline: Returs to Menri monastery
text.text: In late 1948, following his first teacher’s advice, Yongdzin Rinpoche returned to Menri Monastery to complete the rigorous scholastic programme for the Geshe degree (equivalent to a doctorate in philosophy). His principal mentor at Menri was Lopön Sangye Tenzin Rinpoche, one of Bön’s greatest scholars of the era.

text.headline: Received Geshe Degree
text.text: In late 1948, following his first teacher’s advice, Tenzin Namdak returned to Menri Monastery to complete the rigorous scholastic programme for the Geshe degree (equivalent to a doctorate in philosophy). His principal mentor at Menri was Lopön Sangye Tenzin Rinpoche, one of Bön’s greatest scholars of the era. An exceptional student, he mastered the Nine Ways of Bön (the complete spectrum of Bön teachings), Bön logic (tshad-ma), epistemology, the Prajnaparamita (pharchin), Madhyamaka philosophy, monastic discipline, cosmology (dzö), as well as the intricate Mother Tantra (Ma Gyud) and the four major cycles of Dzogchen practice. He became a Geshe in 1952 at the age of 27, graduating with top honours.

text.headline: Appointed Lopön of Menri
text.text: That same year, recognising his profound erudition and insight, the monastery elected him to succeed his teacher as the Lopön (head teaching master) of Menri. Thus, by his mid-twenties, Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche had ascended to one of the highest scholarly and teaching positions in the Bön tradition. More importantly, he had received and safeguarded Bön’s most vital lineages. His teacher, Sangye Tenzin, conferred upon him the single living transmission of the entire Zhang Zhung Nyengyü Dzogchen cycle, making him the sole lineage holder of that profound oral tradition.

text.headline: Disciple Becomes 32nd Abbot of Menri
text.text: Had a divinatory appointment ritual for the appointment of the Menri abbot

text.headline: Spiritual Retreat at Dangra Lake
text.text: Rinpoche entered into a remote retreat at Sezhig Monastery near the sacred Lake Dangra in the northern region. There, he remained in meditation from 1958 to 1960.

text.headline: Captured and Escapes Tibet
text.text: Rinpoche encountered significant challenges in his work and practice in Tibet due to the political upheavals of the 1950s. This tumultuous period brought increasing pressure on monastic institutions. In response to these conditions, Rinpoche was among those who sought refuge outside of Tibet. In 1960, he, along with a small group, embarked on a perilous journey toward the border, aiming for the safety of Nepal or India. Tragically, this endeavour was fraught with danger, as he was shot and subsequently captured, leading to a period of imprisonment that lasted approximately ten months.

text.headline: Arrives in the UK on Rockefeller Grant
text.text: Yongdzin Rinpoche played a pivotal role in both the revival of Bön within the Tibetan exile community and in introducing its teachings to the Western world. His engagement with the West began in the early 1960s, shortly after he settled in India. In 1961, he received an invitation from the esteemed Tibetanologist Professor David Snellgrove at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) in London. With the support of a Rockefeller Foundation grant, Rinpoche travelled to England, where he served as a visiting scholar at both SOAS and the University of Cambridge.

text.headline: Returns to India
text.text: Exile brought significant challenges for Bönpo refugees, who faced marginalisation. Resources were extremely limited, making it a daily struggle to provide food for the monks and new arrivals. In 1964, Rinpoche returned to India, maintaining strong connections with Western scholars. Upon rejoining the Bön community in exile, he had to take on responsibilities that extended beyond those of a typical lama. Out of sheer necessity, he stepped into the roles of community organiser, fundraiser, and construction supervisor.

text.headline: Founds Tibetan Bönpo Foundation in India
text.text: After returning to India and joining the Tibetan refugees, Rinpoche settled in Himachal Pradesh, a northern Indian state, and immediately undertook the significant task of rebuilding the Bön community in exile. By the early 1960s, Bönpo lamas and monks were scattered and living in dire conditions, with no organised support. Rinpoche and a small group of Bönpo refugees recognised that without immediate action, their ancient tradition could easily disappear. From 1964 onwards, he worked tirelessly to establish a permanent base for Bön in exile. In 1966, under his leadership, the Tibetan Bönpo Foundation was formally registered with the Indian government in the indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

text.headline: Establishes Dolanji Tibetan Refugee Settlement
text.text: Following the establishment of the Tibetan Bönpo Foundation, Yongdzin Rinpoche began constructing a refugee settlement, school, and temple. By 1967, about seventy to eighty Bönpo families had been relocated from makeshift camps (such as those in Manali) to the new Dolanji settlement. Rinpoche personally oversaw every aspect of developing this fledgling community. Under makeshift conditions – often with limited resources and only a few surviving monks – he helped re-establish Menri Monastery in exile at the Dolanji site.

text.headline: Publishes *The Nine Ways of Bön*
text.text: In 1961, Yongdzin Rinpoche travelled to Britain to participate in academic and cultural exchanges. Over the following three years, from 1961 to 1964, he immersed himself in studying English—an entirely new language to him at the time—reaching a level that enabled him to teach Tibetan to Western students and share the foundational principles of the Bön tradition. During this period, he formed a significant collaboration with Professor David Snellgrove, laying the groundwork for what would become a landmark scholarly work. In 1967, their joint effort culminated in the publication of *The Nine Ways of Bön* by Oxford University Press. This pioneering book presented translations and detailed explanations of essential Bön texts, including selections from the Ziji, the biography of Buddha Tonpa Shenrab. Widely recognised as the first serious academic study of Yungdrung Bön in the West, the publication dispelled the long-held belief that Buddhism was Tibet’s only spiritual tradition. It ignited international interest in Bön studies and contributed to establishing Bön as a legitimate academic field. Throughout this process, Rinpoche played a vital dual role—not only as a cultural informant but also as a dedicated scholar, ensuring the accuracy and authenticity of the translations. This East–West collaboration marked a turning point in raising global awareness of the ancient Bön tradition.

text.headline: Initiates Menri Monastery in Exile
text.text: With the establishment of the Tibetan Bönpo Foundation and the Dolanji settlement came a profound commitment from Yongdzin Rinpoche to the refugee community. Operating under dire conditions—with only a few surviving monks and scarce resources—Rinpoche led the revival of Menri Monastery in exile at the Dolanji site, revitalising monastic education and ritual practice at the heart of the Bön tradition. Thanks to Rinpoche's relentless organisational leadership and vision, Menri Monastery at Dolanji became not only the spiritual and educational centre of the exile Bön tradition but also one of only two centres in the world—alongside Triten Norbutse in Nepal—offering full Geshe training in Yungdrung Bön.

text.headline: Facilitates Election of 33rd Abbot of Menri
text.text: In 1968, at the newly established Dolanji settlement, Geshe Sangye Tenzin Yongdzin was chosen as the 33rd Menri Trizin—the abbot of Menri Monastery in exile—after a week-long ritual conducted by senior Bön teachers and lamas. The divination and prayers performed in India officially initiated the lineage in exile and marked the formal inauguration of Menri Monastery in Exile. While still in London, Rinpoche played a vital role in organising the traditional election of a new abbot for the exile monastery following the death of the previous one, thereby re-establishing the spiritual leadership of the Bön tradition in exile. Geshe Sangye Tenzin, although abroad at the time, was welcomed back to India from Oslo in November 1969 and was given the name Lungtok Tenpai Nyima. His enthronement officially renewed the spiritual leadership of the exile Bön community.

text.headline: Visiting Scholar at University of Munich
text.text: Rinpoche made a second trip to Europe at the invitation of Professor Helmut Hoffmann in Munich, Germany. There, he served as a visiting scholar at Ludwig Maximilian University, collaborating with Hoffmann on compiling a comprehensive Tibetan-English dictionary. This dictionary project (Wörterbuch der tibetischen Schriftsprache) would continue for decades, with Rinpoche contributing his extensive knowledge of classical Tibetan terminology, including Bön technical terms. Through these academic engagements, he helped make Tibetan literature (both Bön and Buddhist) more accessible to Western researchers.

text.headline: Rebuilds Menri Monastic Life in Exile
text.text: With a new abbot in place to serve as the spiritual head, Rinpoche could concentrate on education and training. He devoted himself to teaching the younger generation of monks and restoring the complete monastic curriculum that had been lost. During the late 1960s and 1970s, he scoured the Tibetan diaspora and the Himalayan regions for Bön texts and oral knowledge. He coordinated efforts to recover Bön manuscripts from remote areas of Nepal and Tibet, where Bön had been practised for centuries. These manuscripts – some of which were the very texts he had hidden or carried away – were brought to India, carefully reprinted in Delhi, and distributed to the newly re-established Bön study centres as well as Western universities.

text.headline: Establishes Dialectic School at Menri
text.text: In 1978, under the guidance of Yongdzin Rinpoche, the Yungdrung Bön Shedrup Lobnyer Dudé college was officially established, reviving the rigorous nine-year Geshe curriculum for the first time in exile. He served as one of its earliest professors, educating a new generation of learned monks. The same year, he bestowed initiation and teachings of the Gyubuchung Cunyi (twelve small tantras) to Choegyal Namkhai Norbu Rinpoche and his students during their visit to Menri Monastery and the Bön settlement for teachings.

text.headline: Devotes Time to Teaching and Writing
text.text:
Through his extraordinary efforts in India, Yongdzin Rinpoche laid the essential foundation for the survival of the Yungdrung Bön tradition. In just two decades, he and a small group of dedicated monks and devotees achieved something truly remarkable: they transformed a fragile community on the brink of extinction into a thriving monastic centre—complete with a functioning abbacy, a growing monastic sangha, a library of sacred texts, and a comprehensive educational system.

This period required immense faith, tireless effort, and profound organisational skill on Rinpoche’s part. While continuing to teach full-time at the dialectic school of Menri Monastery in Dolanji, he also dedicated himself to research, writing, and the transmission of initiations and instructions to a new generation of Bön lamas.

The culmination of this intense phase of engagement and contemplation resulted in the compilation of over 22 authoritative volumes, covering a vast range of topics central to the Bön tradition, including:

- The successive lives of Tonpa Shenrab, the revered founder of Bön, and an exploration of his teachings and their enduring impact on the tradition.
- The history and doctrinal foundations of Yungdrung Bön, detailing the tradition’s development and spiritual significance within the broader landscape of Tibetan religious culture.
- Cosmology, iconography, and the sacred arts, offering insight into the deep interconnection between belief, ritual, and artistic expression in Bön culture.
- Detailed expositions of the Nine Vehicles of Bön, presenting the diverse paths of practice available to followers, each corresponding to varying levels of understanding and spiritual capacity.
- Instructions on meditation and ritual practices, guiding practitioners through both personal and communal spiritual journeys toward realisation and enlightenment.

Through these monumental works, Yongdzin Rinpoche ensured that the profound and subtle knowledge of the Bön tradition would not only survive but flourish, preserved in an authoritative form for future generations to study, practice, and draw inspiration from.

text.headline: Confers First Series of Empowerments
text.text: As a transmission and initiation lineage holder, Yongdzin Rinpoche compassionately granted students, both monastic and lay, a series of initiations (wang), transmissions (lung), and personal instructions (tri). In 1984, Rinpoche conferred the inner, outer, and secret series of empowerments of Yungdrung Bön on both lay and ordained practitioners, including the 33rd abbot of Menri Monastery. This marked the start of many subsequent series of cyclical transmissions Rinpoche would initiate in the years that followed. Later, in the 1990s, Rinpoche bestowed rare tantric transmissions, including the Ma Gyud (Mother Tantra), on Western and Tibetan students.

text.headline: Bestows First Geshe Degree at Menri
text.text: After establishing the Yungdrung Bön Shedrup Lobnyer Dudé college in Dolanji, India, and reviving the complete nine-year Geshe curriculum for Bön at Menri Monastery in exile in 1986, Rinpoche consecrated the Geshe degrees ceremony for the first group of Bön scholars to graduate with Geshe degrees. This milestone signifies the successful transplantation of the Yungdrung Bön intellectual and spiritual lineage to new ground.

text.headline: Returns to Tibet to Bestow Teachings and Transmissions
text.text: Rinpoche returned to Tibet for the first time since his exile from Tibet. During this visit, he shared teachings and transmissions with Bön devotees, travelling to several Bön monasteries in Shigatse, Qamdo, Nagqu, Stengchen, Kongpo, Zingchu, and Amdo Ngaba. He ordained monks, performed rituals and transmissions, and presided over the inauguration ceremony of a new dialectic school at Ri Tsedrug Monastery. Additionally, he appointed the abbot of Dingchen Monastery. His disciples underwent oral examinations, similar to the geshe exam, in front of a congregation of monks led by the head teacher, Kinzang Lodro, at Yungdrung Ling Monastery.

text.headline: Founds Triten Norbutse Monastery
text.text: Beginning with only a handful of monks and modest facilities, Rinpoche initiated the construction of Triten Norbutse, the only major Bön monastery in Kathmandu, Nepal. Rinpoche envisioned a monastery dedicated to the study and practice of the complete Bön teachings, encompassing Sutra, Tantra, and Dzogchen. He replicated and expanded the education system that had been established in Dolanji. By 1994, the monastery had officially instituted a 13-year Geshe degree programme, offering the highest level of academic training in Bön philosophy and sciences.

text.headline: Continues Teaching at Menri in India
text.text: Between 1987 and 1994, Rinpoche, while deeply engaged in the construction of Triten Norbutse, returned to Menri to continue fulfilling his teaching responsibilities.

text.headline: Begins First Western Teaching Tour
text.text: 1989 marked a historic moment in Rinpoche's deep devotion to the global dissemination of Yungdrung Bön. Invited by the International Dzogchen Community of Chögyal Namkhai Norbu, Yogdzin Rinpoche travelled to Italy, England, and the United States, becoming the first Bön master to publicly transmit Dzogchen teachings in the West. Drawing from the Atri and Zhang Zhung Nyengyü traditions, he introduced Western students to foundational and advanced practices such as trekchö, thögel, and calm abiding (zhiné). Rinpoche's clarity, humility, and compassionate presence left a lasting impression, establishing enduring connections and laying the foundation for future Bön centres and study communities across Europe and the Americas.

text.headline: 1989–2018 – Teaches Dzogchen Across the West
text.text: Over nearly three decades, from 1989 to 2018, His Eminence Yongdzin Rinpoche became one of the most influential figures in bringing Bön Dzogchen teachings to the Western world. Responding to invitations from growing international sanghas, he offered teachings in the United States, Argentina, Mexico, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Italy, and Scandinavia. Rinpoche transmitted the heart essence teachings of the Zhang Zhung Nyengyü and Atri lineages to thousands of students, emphasising experiential understanding through trekchö and thögel practices. He held retreats, gave empowerments, and established enduring spiritual relationships with Western practitioners.

text.headline: Attends Kalachakra at the Invitation of H.H. the Dalai Lama
text.text: In a landmark moment for the recognition of the Bön tradition, His Eminence Yongdzin Rinpoche was personally invited by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama to attend the Kalachakra initiation in New York City. Seated among the heads of the Tibetan spiritual traditions, Rinpoche represented Yungdrung Bön on the international stage. This public acknowledgement affirmed Bön's equal status alongside the four major schools of Tibetan Buddhism and symbolised a turning point in inter-traditional respect and unity. Rinpoche's dignified presence and spiritual authority further elevated global awareness of Bön as an authentic and ancient spiritual lineage.

text.headline: Second Return to Tibet for Reviving Lineage and Teaching Across Bön Monasteries
text.text: In 1992, Yongdzin Rinpoche returned to Tibet to support the revival of the Bön tradition in its homeland. During this pivotal journey, he visited numerous historic Bön monasteries across regions, including Nagqu, Qamdo, and his childhood region of Tengchen. He met with heirs of the Shen lineage, including Norbu Wangyal, reaffirming the continuity of the ancient family lineage of Tonpa Shenrab. At each site, Rinpoche bestowed essential transmissions, including initiations (wang), oral transmissions (lung), and direct instructions (tri) to local monks and practitioners. He also performed ritual consecrations, taught sacred ceremonies, and ordained new monks, revitalising monastic life and ensuring the transmission of authentic Bön teachings. His return was received with deep reverence, reestablishing a living connection between the Tibetan homeland and the flourishing Bön tradition in exile.

text.headline: Third Visit to Tibet: Rituals and Lineage Encounters in Lhasa
text.text: In 1994, Yongdzin Rinpoche made his third return to Tibet, with a significant focus on Lhasa. There, he reunited with Shen Norbu Wangyal, a descendant of the ancient Shen lineage, and met his sons, reaffirming ties with the hereditary line of Tonpa Shenrab. Rinpoche also met with the 33rd Abbot of Menri Monastery (in Tibet) during this visit, a historic moment of unity between the exile and homeland branches of the tradition. Together, they performed public rituals for Tibetan devotees, blessing and empowering a large number of practitioners. This visit symbolised a sacred reconnection of the Bön community and strengthened the bridges between East and West, old and new.

text.headline: Inaugurates New Temple and Establishes Dialectic and Meditation Schools at Triten Norbutse
text.text: In 1994, His Eminence Yongdzin Rinpoche consecrated the newly constructed main temple at Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu, marking a major milestone in the monastery's development. This temple became the central sacred space for rituals, teachings, and community practice. In the same year, Rinpoche officially established both the dialectic school (shedra) and the meditation school (drubdra), creating a dual-path monastic education system. The 13-year Geshe curriculum was launched, offering in-depth training in Bön philosophy, cosmology, and logic, while the meditation school focused on advanced practices of Dzogchen, Tantra, and retreat. This comprehensive model ensured that Triten Norbutse would produce both scholars and realised practitioners, securing the future of the Yungdrung Bön lineage for generations to come.

text.headline: Appoints Triten Norbutse Council and Formalises Monastery Structure
text.text: In 1996, Rinpoche took a significant step in the institutional development of Triten Norbutse Monastery by appointing its first official council. The council was entrusted with overseeing the daily operations, education, discipline, and monastic life of the growing community. Rinpoche personally guided the drafting of the monastery's internal structure, roles, and governance functions, ensuring that Triten Norbutse would have a stable, transparent, and sustainable foundation rooted in the principles of Yungdrung Bön. This administrative framework allowed the monastery to expand its programmes, manage resources effectively, and uphold both scholastic and spiritual standards, providing a sense of reassurance about its future.

text.headline: Leads Bön Mandala Project in Osaka, Japan
text.text: In 1997, Yongdzin Rinpoche led a landmark cultural preservation project in collaboration with the National Museum of Ethnology in Osaka, Japan. As the spiritual and academic supervisor, he oversaw the meticulous painting of 130 mandalas based on authoritative Bön ritual and meditation texts. The project aimed to document, preserve, and exhibit the rich visual heritage of the Bön tradition for both scholarly and public audiences. Rinpoche provided guidance on the iconographic accuracy of each mandala, ensured faithful representation of esoteric symbolism, and instructed the team on the corresponding ritual significance. He also advised on the writing and publication of the Mandalas of the Bön Religion. This comprehensive volume, which accompanied the exhibit, remains a vital resource for understanding the Bön religion's tantric arts. This initiative significantly raised international awareness of Bön's profound aesthetic and spiritual traditions.

text.headline: Fourth Return to Tibet: Teachings, Ordinations, and Institutional Revitalisation
text.text: In 1999, His Eminence Yongdzin Rinpoche made his fourth return to Tibet, continuing his mission to revitalise the Bön tradition in its ancestral land. He reunited with Shen Norbu Wangyal once again and visited several important Bön monasteries in the Tengchen and Bachen regions. During this visit, Rinpoche consecrated sacred spaces, bestowed initiations and transmissions, and ordained new monks, providing essential support to local communities that have been working to restore Bön practices after decades of suppression. A major highlight of the trip was the inauguration of the dialectic school (shedra) at Tengchen Monastery, which revived advanced scholastic training in the region. Rinpoche also sponsored and initiated the establishment of a Tibetan medical school in Tengchen County, expanding his efforts beyond religion to include the preservation of traditional Tibetan healing knowledge. This journey reinforced his deep commitment to the spiritual, cultural, and educational rebirth of Bön in Tibet.

text.headline: Bestowing First Geshe Degree at Triten Norbutse Monastery
text.text: In 2001, Yongdzin Rinpoche bestowed the first Geshe degree at Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu, marking a historic milestone in the monastery's development. This event signified the successful completion of the full 13-year philosophical training curriculum initiated in the early 1990s under Rinpoche's guidance. The conferral of the Geshe degree—equivalent to a doctorate in Bön philosophy—not only affirmed the academic and spiritual rigour of Triten Norbutse's shedra but also fulfilled Rinpoche's vision of reestablishing a complete lineage of qualified Bön scholars in exile. This moment affirmed the monastery's standing as one of the foremost centres for Bön education in the world.

text.headline: Electing the abbot of Triten Norbutse
text.text: In the same year as the conferment of the first Geshe degrees at Triten Norbutse, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche formally appointed his close disciple, Jeru Geshe Tenpa Yungdrung Rinpoche, as the first abbot of Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu. This marked an important step in ensuring the continuity of the monastery's spiritual and administrative leadership.

text.headline: Bestows Series of Secret Empowerments at Triten Norbutse
text.text: In 2001, His Eminence Yongdzin Rinpoche bestowed a rare and powerful series of secret empowerments (sang wang) to both the monastic and lay communities at Triten Norbutse Monastery. These empowerments, which included advanced tantric and Dzogchen transmissions, were given as part of Rinpoche's effort to ensure the full transmission of the experiential and ritual dimensions of the Yungdrung Bön tradition.

text.headline: Founds Shenten Dargye Ling Retreat Centre in France
text.text: In 2005, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche founded Shenten Dargye Ling, a dedicated Bön retreat centre in the Loire Valley of France. Established with the support of European disciples and the generous offering of land by Loel Guinness, Shenten Dargye Ling became the first major Bön institution in the West designed for long-term study and meditation. That same year, Bön was officially recognised by the French government as a legal religious congregation, affirming its status within Europe. Under Rinpoche's direct guidance, the centre developed a full programme of Dzogchen retreats, philosophical seminars, and translation work, serving as a sister institution to Triten Norbutse and a gateway for Western practitioners to receive authentic Bön teachings.

text.headline: Publishes 13-Volume Collected Works in India
text.text: In 2005, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche's collected Tibetan writings were published in a 13-volume set in India, marking a monumental contribution to the preservation of Bön literature. These volumes encompass a vast range of subjects, including Dzogchen, Tantra, Sutra, cosmology, rituals, logic, and monastic discipline, offering deep insights into the philosophical and experiential heart of the Yungdrung Bön tradition. Compiled and edited under Rinpoche's guidance, the collection ensures that future generations of practitioners and scholars have access to authentic, authoritative sources. This publication is widely regarded as one of the most significant literary achievements in the history of Bön in exile.

text.headline: French Government Recognises Shenten Dargye Ling as a Religious Congregation
text.text: In 2006, the French government's Ministry of the Interior officially recognised Shenten Dargye Ling as a legal religious congregation. This recognition marked a historic moment for the Yungdrung Bön tradition in the West, affirming its legitimacy and religious status in France. Initiated and spiritually guided by His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche, Shenten Dargye Ling has become not only a retreat centre but also a legally recognised spiritual institution. This milestone ensured the long-term stability of Bön's presence in Europe and supported its growing community of Western practitioners dedicated to the study, meditation, and transmission of the Bön teachings.

text.headline: Relocates Tibetan Medical School to Triten Norbutse
text.text: In 2006, under the guidance of His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche, the Tibetan Medical School originally established in Dhorpatan was relocated to Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu. This strategic move integrated traditional medical education into the broader framework of monastic learning, allowing aspiring Tibetan doctors to study in a vibrant, spiritually rooted environment. The relocation also enhanced accessibility for students and facilitated collaboration between scholars of medicine, philosophy, and ritual.

text.headline: Final Return to Tibet and Ordains 150 Monks
text.text: In 2007, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche made his final return to Tibet, culminating decades of tireless dedication to the revitalisation of Yungdrung Bön in its homeland. During this deeply significant journey, Rinpoche met again with Shen Norbu Wangyal and Gyalse Yungdrung Gyalwa, offering teachings and primary practice transmissions to members of the Shen family—descendants of the founder of Bön, Tonpa Shenrab. He also met with hundreds of devoted practitioners from across Tibet, giving empowerments, oral transmissions, and guidance. A major highlight of this visit was the ordination of over 150 new monks, strengthening the foundation of monastic life for future generations. Rinpoche also took time to identify and visit several ancient Bön sacred sites, reaffirming their spiritual importance and inspiring their continued veneration. This final visit symbolised the full-circle return of the living Bön lineage to its source, supported by Rinpoche's lifelong mission of compassionate transmission and preservation.

text.headline: Visits Zhu Rizhing and Blesses New Educational Sites in India
text.text: In 2007, His Eminence Yongdzin Rinpoche visited Zhu Rizhing Yungdrung Kundragling, a growing Bön community in India, where he inaugurated the newly established meditation school, further expanding access to contemplative training outside Nepal and Tibet. During the same journey, Rinpoche visited the newly acquired site for the future Sheing Phunthogling Bön Society school, offering blessings and guidance for its development. He also consecrated the land for what would become the Tise Himalayan International School, a visionary educational project initiated by Triten Norbutse Monastery to integrate traditional Bön values with modern education. These blessings and initiations signified Rinpoche's continued commitment to fostering Bön education and ensuring that future generations would benefit from both inner wisdom and outer learning.

text.headline: Oversees Stupa Construction at Shenten Dargye Ling
text.text: In 2009, Yongdzin Rinpoche presided over the construction of the Yungdrung Löeg Stupa at Shenten Dargye Ling in France. This stupa, embodying the essence of indestructible wisdom and the unchanging nature of reality, was built under Rinpoche's spiritual direction as a source of blessing and inspiration for all practitioners. He carefully guided the architectural symbolism, consecration rituals, and selection of sacred relics to be enshrined within the structure. The completion of the stupa marked a significant spiritual milestone for the Western Bön community, establishing a sacred foundation for practice and a tangible expression of Yungdrung Bön's flourishing presence in Europe.

text.headline: Sends Sacred Relics Back to Menri Monastery in Tibet
text.text: In 2010, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche arranged for the return of two sacred images to the original Menri Monastery in Tibet—relics he had personally safeguarded since his escape from Tibet in 1960. Before fleeing, Rinpoche had foreseen the impending destruction and taken extraordinary steps to protect Bön's most treasured spiritual treasures. At a remote cave in Lug-do Drag in the Tsochen area, he concealed the revered relic stupa of Nyame Sherab Gyaltsen—one of Bön's greatest saints—along with statues and numerous sacred objects to shield them from looting and desecration. He also carried with him, at great personal risk, several volumes of irreplaceable Bön scriptures, including the complete Oral Transmission of the Zhang Zhung Nyengyüd and other essential texts. Thanks to this remarkable foresight and devotion, Rinpoche preserved the flame of Yungdrung Bön through one of the darkest periods in its history. Decades later, those very relics and texts became instrumental in reviving the tradition in exile. Their return to Menri in 2010 was not merely a symbolic moment—it was the culmination of Rinpoche's lifelong vow to protect and restore the sacred heritage of Bön in its native land.

text.headline: Completes Dzogchen Transmission to Western Lay Practitioners
text.text: Between 2010 and 2015, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche bestowed the complete transmission of the Zhang Zhung Nyengyü and the Kagyud Korzhi—the Four Cycles of Dzogchen Teachings—to Western lay practitioners attending the annual summer retreats at Shenten Dargye Ling in France. These years marked the first time in history that such profound teachings, traditionally reserved for advanced monastics, were fully transmitted to a dedicated community of lay practitioners in the West. Rinpoche personally gave empowerments (wang), oral transmissions (lung), and detailed instructions (tri), ensuring the authentic and unbroken continuation of the Dzogchen lineage outside Tibet. This transmission laid the foundation for a new generation of committed Dzogchen practitioners, reflecting Rinpoche's deep trust in the sincerity and capacity of his Western disciples.

text.headline: Guides 34th Abbot Election at Menri Monastery
text.text: In 2017, following the passing of His Holiness the 33rd Menri Trizin Lungtok Tenpai Nyima, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche played a pivotal role in guiding the selection process for the 34th Abbot of Menri Monastery. Drawing from his deep spiritual authority and decades-long leadership within the Bön tradition, Rinpoche provided clear instructions to ensure that the election process upheld the lineage's integrity, ritual protocols, and traditional procedures. His guidance ensured a smooth transition of spiritual leadership, ultimately resulting in the unanimous selection of Geshe Dawa Dhargye, the 34th Menri Trizin, as the new abbot. This moment marked the continuity of the Menri throne and reaffirmed Rinpoche's unwavering commitment to preserving Bön's institutional and spiritual legacy.

text.headline: Blesses 34th Abbot and Supports Opening of Tise Himalayan School in India
text.text: In 2018, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche formally blessed the newly enthroned 34th Menri Trizin at Menri Monastery, offering his heartfelt prayers and spiritual support for the continued leadership and unity of the Bön tradition. That same year, he actively supported the establishment of the Tise Himalayan International School in India, an educational initiative aimed at preserving Himalayan culture while providing a modern curriculum. Later in the year, Rinpoche presided over the Dutrisu ritual ceremony during the autumn retreat at Shenten Dargye Ling in France, further reaffirming his lifelong dedication to the flourishing and protection of Yungdrung Bön across both Eastern and Western lands.

text.headline: Begins Construction of New Temple at Triten Norbutse
text.text: In 2019, under the guidance of His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche, construction began on a new temple at Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu. This expansion reflected the growing monastic community and the increasing number of students drawn to the study and practice of Yungdrung Bön. The new temple was envisioned as a sacred space to host major rituals, empowerments, and advanced teachings, continuing Rinpoche's mission to provide a strong institutional and spiritual foundation for future generations.

text.headline: Celebrates 95th Birthday with Devotees
text.text: In 2020, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche joyfully celebrated his 95th birthday, a momentous occasion that brought together thousands of devotees from across the world. Disciples from both Eastern and Western countries gathered—physically and virtually—to honour the extraordinary life, wisdom, and compassion of one of the greatest living masters of the Yungdrung Bön tradition. The celebration was marked by heartfelt tributes, offerings, and prayers, expressing gratitude for Rinpoche's lifelong service in preserving and transmitting the Bön teachings.

text.headline: Publishes Complete 22-Volume Collected Works
text.text: In 2021, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche completed the publication of his 22-volume Collected Works, representing the most comprehensive compilation of his writings to date. This monumental collection comprises both newly published texts and a revised second edition of his earlier 13-volume set. The works span the full breadth of the Yungdrung Bön tradition, including Dzogchen, Tantra, Sutra, cosmology, ritual, monastic discipline, and philosophical commentaries. Edited and published under Rinpoche's direct supervision, the collection serves as a lasting scholarly and spiritual legacy, offering future generations an authoritative foundation for study and practice. It stands as a testament to Rinpoche's extraordinary contribution to the preservation and flourishing of Bön's sacred literature in exile.

text.headline: Moves into New Residence at Completed Temple
text.text: In 2024, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche moved into his newly completed residence within the expanded temple complex at Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu.

text.headline: Inaugurates New Temple During Centennial Celebration
text.text: In 2025, during the grand centennial celebration of his 100th birthday, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche officially inaugurated the newly completed temple at Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu. Surrounded by disciples, monks, and international guests, the ceremony marked both a spiritual and historical milestone, honouring a century of Rinpoche's life dedicated to preserving and spreading the Yungdrung Bön tradition. The inauguration was accompanied by ritual ceremonies, prayers, and offerings, consecrating the space as a lasting support for Bön practice and transmission. The temple stands as a crowning achievement of Rinpoche's vision and compassion, embodying the strength and continuity of the tradition he so tirelessly upheld.

text.headline: 100th Birthday Celebration
text.text: In 2025, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche's 100th birthday was joyously celebrated with over 6,000 devotees from across the world. The centennial event, held at Triten Norbutse Monastery in Kathmandu, was one of the largest gatherings in the history of the Bön tradition. Monks, nuns, scholars, practitioners, and students from more than 30 countries came together to honour Rinpoche's extraordinary century of life and spiritual service. The celebration included teachings, long-life offerings, ritual ceremonies, musical performances, and the inauguration of the new temple, symbolising both deep reverence for Rinpoche and the flourishing of the Bön lineage into the next century.

text.headline: Enters Thukdam and Parinirvana
text.text: On June 12, 2025, during the auspicious month of Saga Dawa, His Eminence Yongdzin Lopön Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche passed away peacefully, entering the profound meditative state of Thukdam. This sacred moment marked the Parinirvana of one of the greatest living masters of the Yungdrung Bön tradition. His departure was met with deep reverence and mourning across the global Bön community, as disciples, monastic institutions, and practitioners gathered to pay homage and carry out traditional rituals. Rinpoche's passing during Saga Dawa—a time associated with the enlightenment and Parinirvana of the Buddha—was seen as a sign of his extraordinary spiritual realisation. Though his physical presence departed, the light of his teachings and blessings continues to guide countless beings.
